item.title: How culture has affected natural selection in man
item.description: Culture is arguably unique to humans. It possibly arose from the need to manage larger groups of people that congregated near agricultural fields as Jared Diamond suggests in Guns, Germs and Steel1 although it may have originated in tribal or hunter-gatherer societies. It is strongly linked with religion which can viewed as a cement holding together larger population masses. Recent developments in its research suggests two perspectives of culture: an outcome of natural selection which considers humans part of “nature” and culture as a purely human construct which arose as a consequence of advanced emotional intelligence which natural selection (according to believers of this theory) cannot explain. In order to see the effects on natural selection, one has to take a neutral stance.

item.title: Sustainability and the Common Man
item.description: Policy with respect to sustainability in India has never been top priority, until very recently. It has often been fraught with people’s predispositions that should never have come about in the first place. I will be talking about the ways of a singe man I know, let’s call him Devdas (original name withheld for various reasons) and how almost all of his actions were made knowing about the state of wildlife in India.
